pros: Great education institution. Best on-campus experience and facilities. Warwick University is a "plate glass" campus university established in 1965 on the outskirts of Coventry. Its reputation has rapidly risen to be regarded as one of the top 10 ranking universities in the UK and offers a wide range of traditional university courses. It is a member of the Russell Group of research intensive universities.
cons: The University is located just on the outskirts of Coventry. There is a regular bus into Coventry from the University, Coventry has a good cinema, ice skating rink, laser quest, good restaurants and quite a lot of shops. The bus into Coventry goes past the Coventry Train Station which has direct trains going to Birmingham often, which has a large shopping centre, The Bull Ring, which has some really good shops. Including this Birmingham hosts a Christmas German Market in December which is worth a visit. The University has a walking route to the town of Kenilworth, which has the ruins of Kenilworth castle, on the whole Kenilworth is a nice picturesque town which is worth a visit. The historic market town of Stratford-upon-Avon is fairly close to the University as well, this has quite a few museums about William Shakespeare. Royal Leamington Spa is also close to the university and reachable by bus, in fact many second and third year students choose to live here, as a result it is a popular destination for nights out.

job_title: Warwick Retail Staff Member in Coventry, England
pros: Relatively flexible hours, access to either term-time or full-time contracts (useful if you have a family or commitments). As a full-time contracted member of staff, you are very unlikely to lose your job. Good training opportunities.
cons:
As a member of staff of one of Warwick Retail outlets, the pay is really low, a little over minimum wage, and it's pretty clear that your well being is not exactly a priority for the University. There's no such thing as a Christmas bonus, a raise or any type of recognition for your good performances, even when your outlet has achieved a significant increase in sales.
Some members of the upper management are particularly rude and ungrateful, not treating their staff with the respect they deserve. 
Also, a promotion can be quite hard to achieve in some of the outlets, as the number of available position is very limited, and nepotism is not uncommon.
Products sold in cafes and restaurants are not the best quality, and sometimes can be frustrating having to sell something that is visibly poor.

review_title: A flexible employer who pushes you to succeed and develop your career
job_title: Digital Signage Content Executive in Stratford-upon-Avon, England
pros: I love working here because the team is large with varied experiences.  Everyone is very passionate and cares about what they do.  I have autonomy in my role and am supported when trying new things.  Everyone is encouraged to develop their skills and careers rather than stand still.  The benefits are fabulous too and it's a very flexible place for work/life balance etc.  The on-site Sports Centre is a bonus for me and I can't wait to try out the new Sports Hub when it opens next Spring.  People love working here, which is obvious by the number of years some people have been here!
cons: I can't think of anything which would be a con for working here.  I can honestly say I love it!  I suppose the only downside would be the parking issues, and having to pay for parking.  Also the food is the University House cafe is rubbish and expensive.  Minor issues!

review_title: Great place to work with a great environment
pros: Flexible time, getting to work with new technology and work on things that I myself find interesting even if those higher up haven't heard of them. Very good relationship with customers (staff and students at the University) and nominated for a number of awards for use of new media. A happy and friendly community with great people.
cons: Sometimes expected to work outside of work hours to firefight without any real support or appreciation from non-direct senior management (i.e. senior management that doesn't include my team leader or line manager). General bad impression of the IT department as a whole within the University (although a favourable impression of the web development team)

review_title: Superbly capable and professional people here.
pros:
All the academic staff from post-doctoral level and upwards who I have come across have been superbly capable and impressive professionals. Research groups are well-resourced and lots of support is given to all junior workers. The university, library and departments are responsive to requests and criticisms you may have and it is always possible to get things done.

The Mathematics Institute and the Centre for Scientific Computing are excellent. Biological Sciences is very good with fantastic central organization and strong research groups. There is good cooperation between departments and senior academics are able to get people to work well together despite the difficulty in not understanding a foreign research perspective at the beginning.

Fantastic location and campus.
cons: The Chemistry Department suffers from low undergraduate entrance requirements resulting in people of questionable ability and forces employment of externals who are equally questionable.

review_title: Good employer, good pay, reasonable job security
job_title: User Support ICT & AV in Coventry, England
pros: Pleasant working environment, campus & Amenities.  Budget for training.  If scope increases then resource usually does too.  Good pay relative to role and reasonable pension too.  Clear company strategy communicated well.
cons: Limited promotion opportunity as people 'stay' in position.  High average length of service and little churn.  Parking on site can be limited as new buildings swallow up parking capacity.  Gaining employment there can be difficult as permanent roles often only advertised once they have someone in mind.  Temp & temp to perm opportunity is there via Unitemps recruitment.

pros: I enjoyed this job a lot - I was trusted to make decisions and work alone despite being on a relatively low pay grade. Not that the pay was bad, I was just fairly junior. I was treated respectfully by my superiors and the atmosphere was always one of camaraderie. Occasional overtime available which even my manager took in order to meet deadlines: he wasn't above getting his hands dirty. He was fairly young too which you can take as a good indication of possibilities for career advancement.
cons: Minimal 'perks' : you get your salary and that's about it. I didn't find this bothered me to be honest.

review_title: Exceptional staff, state of the art facilities and a great place!
pros: Its country! You're not in some noisy, polluted city. The 700 acre campus just redifines the word 'work'. The staff (people you work with) are all exceptional. And thats not because Warwick only hires the best (I certainly wasnt 'good' at what I do when I started. Warwick just has a way of allowing you to reach your true potential. it showed me the door, and motivates me to walk through it every second of my life.
cons: If you don't have a group of 'work friends' it can get very isolating. The 'company' structure is so well defined, its robotic. So if you need help, you're on your own.

review_title: I was an Undergraduate Open Day Helper, and working within this capacity was very rewarding!
job_title: Undergraduate Open Day Helper in Coventry, England
pros: The hourly pay rate is excellent for the type of work involved, and we also got holiday pay, which was an unexpected bonus.  Training was available for people carrying out tours, and we were all given guidelines in case we were asked any unexpected or awkward questions!
cons: Sometimes it was quite hard to strike up enthusiasm in the prospective students, but eventually they would overcome their shyness.

review_title: Different to most universities, with benefits and cons.
pros:
Excellent facilties and funding, and different departments are generally very collaborative and happy to share resources. 

There is space for the university to expand unlike many other city based universities. The place is a continual construction site.
cons: Very business oriented and it can feel more like a business park at times. Sometimes its hard to differentiate between the campus and JLR's facilities here.

review_title: I will NOT advise coming to UoW for postgraduate studies
pros:
efficient supply, ordering and prep-room facilities
high exposure to talks covering wide range of topics
cons:
- Interdisciplinary or any innovative work requiring access to facilities, new model organisms, or even just a collaborative work is passively but efficiently suppressed by a labyrinth of safety requirements which can not be even evaluated ahead of time co'z nobody can tell you what is the process.
 
Example: before diving into a new project, you start with some reasonable paperwork and end up hunting for a signature by a designated person who is available once a month. Then you are told the signature is not sufficient and the paperwork is sent for another evaluation which will take take several weeks. The attitude is semi-rude and the comments are bewildering - each side says different things. The whole way of doing this safety evaluation suggests that the idea of doing something new is irrelevant and invasive. After idle attempts for three-four months, you realize the true state of things, give up and try to make up on the wasted time with some in-hand methods. No collaboration. No potentially exciting project.

- IT support is more of an obstacle
Examples: 
  you arrive to a workshop and discover that, despite a proper early notice, IT did not manage to install the required software. You can not install it yourself as the computers are locked for new installations.
   
  IT will not help you with any problem related to your privet computer even if the software required for your research runs on PC only and you use your own computer to run this software. They do not support PCs in general. No discrimination here, just a rule.

  In general, what matters here is your personal relationship with the IT guys. If you are lucky to be pretty young female - you may get the password required  to install any software of your machine. If you are just another research stuff, male, no blond - you may wait for a month (no exaggeration here!) for your software to be installed. 
Besides this, UoW is short on the number of I-net plugs. So you get a table and then are told that there is no I-net port available and you have to wait until somebody will leave and inherit you his/her port. 

- Working place: There is NO respect for the "thinking" part of research - you are placed in a walk-through room with 20 other people, with no privacy whatsoever, no proper ventilation, slamming doors and poor lightening and are expected to find it a productive environment.
The office furniture is from 80s - 3 chairs I have tried were all broken. Not enough power points = we have chains of extensions running under our tables.

On the other hand, money is invested in all the open spaces e.g. cafeteria, halls etc. People are of a less value that the look of this place.

Recently they removed kitchenettes and installed water coolers. But nor kettles, no hot water. A glass of hot water in cafeteria is 50p.

WCs... you must manage flushing only once! co'z after you flush - it takes 6-7 mins to get the water tank refilled. The results = restrooms are rarely clean in afternoons.

Recycling bins have recently been installed and you get an email that trash bins in offices will be emptied once a week to "encourage" you to recycle. By the end of week, all the organics that can not be recycled and are dumped in the office bins stink. I am afraid to this what will happen in summer.

Bottom line - very much in UoW is invested to make up the place as cool and nice and great. Unfortunately, after some time you discover that it's a very provincial University that tries to grab as many students as possible without investing neither in its people nor in its research facilities. 

If you are looking for a PhD or a post training - I would suggest skipping this Uni, unless there is no better place to go.

review_title: Teaching Fellow at the Economics Department
pros: Great work/life balance. Friendly environment.  Moderate workload, generous deadlines. The most efficient and best organised departmental administration that I have ever seen. The opportunity to work with our students is refreshing and  stimulating. I highly recommend the sports center - it is amazing.
cons: Limited opportunities of professional growth. Noncompetitive salary. Limited progression, with quality of work being irrelevant. Co-workers who are not always the most competent. Considerable marking workload.   In hot periods expect 70 hours working week.

pros: Top level academic environment, surrounded by excellent people, good support and access to the latest equipment. In my department I was respected and treated like a colleague despite technically still being a student. The location is great; easy to get to both London and Birmingham by train, close to Birmingham airport, Coventry city nearby and effectively in the countryside.
cons: Not well known internationally, but this is changing. The buildings are very modern, which is not to some people's taste.

pros: Calm and friendly work environment, very helpful colleagues and line managers, amazing campus, cutting edge facilities and laboratories, the company and the managers fully support the employees to learn new skills.
cons:

The hiring process is a 'closed-circle'... the candidates have a higher possibility to get hired only if they have studied at the University of Warwick (i.e. have paid a lot of money), or if they have previous professional collaboration with them.

review_title: Good for ambitious people, not that great for academics

pros: Warwick Conferences is a great place to work, especially as a student. The management team is very professional and always makes sure all conferences and events are run smoothly. As a conference assistant, I have worked with a generous number of clients, from business to academic background, which is a positive aspect of the job.
cons: Sometimes there are not many shifts available to everybody. You do not know from the beginning of the month your schedule or anticipate your earnings.

review_title: Great office with interesting work and lovely people
pros: I've worked across many different departments during my time at University of Warwick - there is a vibrancy in the open plan, 150 person office more than one might expect. The jobs are interesting and varied, the management is excellent, and the environment is truly lovely.
cons: Aren't many cons I could think of. Salary, progression etc. isn't as high as I'd like, but it's the nature of the job.

pros: A nice campus and facilities
cons: I would not advise working here especially if you are a middle aged woman.  In my experience there are too many overqualified middle aged women stuck in low paid clerical jobs without an opportunity to progress. It is completely demoralising environment and full of nepotism.  Too many barriers and a "them vs us" attitude between academics and clerical workers.

review_title: Terrible, senior management treat the majority of staff really poorly, they are driven by trying to rise up rankings
